attributes.alt: Cover for Everybunny Dance! by Ellie Sandall. Cover shows rabbits dancing and playing musical instruments in the grass.

elements.text: Read-Aloud Comprehension; Alphabet Knowledge; Phonological Awareness
Use Circle Time to introduce the letters
, engage children with dancing, and introduce a new vocabulary word
Begin Story Time by introducing the Big Book and asking,
In what ways do the animals have fun?
React to a variety of musical styles through movement and play.
Drawing paper, crayons, yellow paper circles
Ask children to wiggle their fingers if a word begins like
and hold up a yellow circle if a word begins like
Invite children to draw a wiggly worm and a yellow yo-yo.
How can we express ourselves through music and dance?
What characters are in your book? How do they move?
What storybook animal will you pretend to be? How will you move while you are pretending?
How can you sort these objects? What groups will you have?
How can you use these things to make music?
What are you building? What materials will you use?

attributes.alt: Cover for Everybunny Dance! by Ellie Sandall. Cover shows rabbits dancing and playing musical instruments in the grass.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to share the Mind Builder
and introduce a related vocabulary word
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to
Read closely and notice when the characters make connections.
Engage in movement sequences with adult prompts.
React to a variety of musical styles through movement and play.
Guide children to name different ways to move.
Help children develop executive function and gross motor skills by taking steps to do three new actions in sequence.
How can we express ourselves through music and dance?
What do the characters in this story do for fun?
Make up a dance. Show different ways to move.
What parts of your body do you use when you dance?
Make up a silly song that is  about bunnies.
Make a musical instrument. What materials will you use?
Show me the letter that begins
. Show me the letter that begins
Can you make a place the bunnies can hide when they see the fox?

attributes.alt: Cover for Everybunny Dance! by Ellie Sandall. Cover shows rabbits dancing and playing musical instruments in the grass.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to build background and engage children in a chant.
What are some ways the animals dance?
Make plans and take steps towards a goal.
Distinguish words that sound similar but have different meanings.
Engage in movement sequences with adult prompts.
Show interest and appreciation for others’ work.
Help children learn to blend phonemes to say one-syllable words with pictorial support:
fox, dog, and cat. Write the first letter of each animal name.
How can we express ourselves through music and dance?
How is the character in your book like the characters in the story we read today?
Why do you move differently to different kinds of music?  Materials: scarves, fans to experiment with dance/movement, recorded music.
Why do these instruments have different sounds?
Think of some words that describe dancing. Can you write about dancing?
How can you make a picture that shows children moving?
. Why do you need a letter
Why do you need a letter
Can you build a drum? What materials will you use?

elements.text: Big Chart of Big Ideas:  Old MacDonald’s Farm

attributes.alt: Cover for Everybunny Dance! by Ellie Sandall. Cover shows rabbits dancing and playing musical instruments in the grass.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to talk about farm animals, play a rhyming game and introduce the vocabulary word
Start Story Time by connecting the texts,
Read closely to answer the weekly concept question,
How can we express ourselves through music and dance?
Distinguish words that sound similar but have different meanings.

attributes.alt: Big Chart of Big Ideas for Old MacDonald's Farm. Chart shows a horse, a cow, goats, ducks, chicks, and a chicken in front of a farmhouse.

elements.text: Big Chart of Big Ideas: Old MacDonald’s Farm
Help children identify pairs of rhyming words.
Share rhyming word pairs with children and have them use them to play a matching game.
How can we express ourselves through music  and dance?
Which do you like better, stories or songs? Why?
What is your favorite kind farm animal? Why?
Compare these toy animals. How can you sort them?
What animal would you like to write a song about?
Make a baby farm animal and its mom. Which one of them should be bigger?
Think of a farm animal. What sound does it begin with?
What blocks can you use to build Old MacDonald’s Farm?

attributes.alt: Cover for Everybunny Dance! by Ellie Sandall. Cover shows rabbits dancing and playing musical instruments in the grass.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to have children act out and describe favorite pretend play and introduce vocabulary
What are some ways we sing, dance, and play like the bunnies?
Share and repeat the details  in a text.
Engage in movement sequences with adult prompts.
Sing, play musical instruments, and move to the rhythm in classroom activities.
Act out to recreate and retell stories, moods, or experiences.
Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt:
What is your favorite way to express yourself through music and dance?
Save children’s responses to display next week.
How can we express ourselves through music  and dance?
What is your favorite book in the library now? Why?
Imagine you are a bunny or a fox. What will you do?
Can you use pattern blocks to make an animal?
Would you like to play the drums or blow a horn? Write about the one you like.
Which part of your work today do you like best?
Can you make up names for some of the bunnies? How will you spell them?
Which blocks would be most helpful to use to build a house for a bunny?

Use information learned from books by describing, relating, categorizing, or comparing and contrasting.
Produce at least 20 distinct letter-sound correspondences in the language of instruction.

Retell or reenact a story after it is read aloud.
Move from scribbles to some letter-sound correspondence using beginning and ending sounds when writing.

Participate in classroom music activities, including singing, playing musical instruments, and moving to rhythms.
